That was painful to watch. I feel so bad for Jack Horner. The public has been totally left behind by paleontology. In the beginning, Jurassic Park was meant in part to help give people their first modern image of what dinosaurs were really like, according to the science of the time. In the quarter century since then, so many advancements have been made, but the franchise still portrays the same scaly green movie monsters, for the sake of "continuity" (not risking profits). We now have real dinosaurs with venomous bites, dinosaurs with three-foot claws, dinosaurs with bat-like wings, real color patterns for some species, and of course, feathers galore. Those things could easily have reinvigorated the public's fascination with dinosaurs, but what did we get instead? A purely fictional, spiny Tyrannosaurus-cuttlefish hybrid with more teeth. Sad.

To those wondering why we can't clone dinosaurs using the DNA form fossils it's because DNA has a half-life of some tens of thousands of years (maybe 60 000, I don't remember exactly), which completely erases the possibility to clone the exact same specimens because they went extinct 65 million years ago. This means that we can however, clone more recently extinct animals like sabertooths or mammoths. I'm actually kinda surprised they didn't mention that in the video.

Do you think that humans will gain intelligence and knowledge and become a better species in the future (say a thousand years)?

I don't think so. I think that human intelligence will have decreased in a thousand years and will become a less knowledgeable and worse species. The theory behind this is that humans are starting to get more reliant on technology. The first ever innovation, fire, allowed human skulls to become thinner and grow bigger and better brains which allowed us to gain traits that no other species had ever gained on Earth. As time went on technology improved and helped us with our tasks, making our lives easier for us.

Then there became a point, in the late 20th century, where humans started to rely on technology to live with the rise of computers and the internet (e.g. money transaction relies heavily on networks and storage units). We have allowed computers to become so vital that no access to ICT for a modern and developed civilization for a prolonged period of time will spell disaster for everyone in that civilization.

Computers and machines have taken over tasks that humans used to do which makes our lives easier but we gradually loose skills that were necessary to survive in an older world without machines. As time goes on, the need for these skills slowly fade away and there will be a generation that would never have any necessary skills as they will not need to learn them.

A world where humans rely entirely on machines to do basic tasks and use our intelligence for us would mean that this future generation would not need to use their brain.This lack of usage of intelligence would mean that there will be a point where humans will have a far lower intelligence than today.

Now imagine a catastrophe where the machines that this future generation relies on so desperately failed. What would happen to them? They would suffer and because they lack basic skills they would not be able to survive for long and possibly the human race could be extinct. Also, we would forget how the machine that we rely on works as we would take it for granted and therefore we wouldn't be able to repair it.

In the 1950s, if the machines that were needed failed and couldn't be repaired for a prolonged period of time we would have done fine (even though it would've been a bit of a nuisance) because we weren't reliant on technology. If the exact same thing happens now we will be seriously fucked.

To those wondering "Derp-a-derp, why didn't everything die?!"  Well, because what do birds eat? Each other and insects and fish. What survived since the beginning of time? insect, fish and birds. WHat else survived? Just about everything that was not substantially cold-blooded. Any mammals would have likely been small redent sized creatures that digged DEEP and lived off of small things similar to what the birds ate. Any large reptiles or other large creatures that survived, only did so because they likely were dependent on there being water. i.e. komodo dragons, alligators, crocodiles, which depending the species were either more or less fantastic way back then. There were quite a lot of other large sea-based creatures that had survived, but their source of food was annihilated if they acquired anything on land, and many of the large oceanic reptiles still hunted on shorelines.

Another thing, dinosaurs pretty much for the most part stayed far away from both freezing and tropical places. Their landscape was very VERY limited looking at the shape of the continents then. The oceans were still dominant and any land bridges sucked.

You do know you are pushing information about dinosaurs that has been proven wrong as if  they where facts.
There is evidence that in at least some cases these so-called feathered dinosaurs are really misidentified birds. Also, most of these fossils are from China, of which they are known to have a fake fossil industry.

The archaeopteryx is one of the most famous and  is said to be one a primary example of a dinosaur in a transitional phase. Others believe it to be merely another hoax, like that of the archaeoraptor in which pieces of different animals were put together to form another species.
Leading experts in both the creationist and evolutionary worlds agree that the archaeopteryx is indeed a true organism. Dr. David Menton, a creationist anatomist, shows how it is a true bird with feathers capable of flight. He says it is neither a transitional form nor a feathered dinosaur, but a bird. Dr. Alan Feduccia, an evolutionist, is a bird expert at the University of North Carolina. He too agrees that the archaeopteryx is a perching bird, not a dinosaur like many others claim

there is one thing i dont get though, he was so certain that the jurassic park method of cloning dinosaurs is pure fiction...but that's not entirely true, obviously the idea with the mosquito getting fossilized in amber is not by any means a plausible idea, but flash freezing has the potential to keep the animal (with its dna) intact. And if you have just one cell with a full set of chromosomes than you can clone it. Some of you may remember Dolly the sheep, they took the full set of chromosomes from a cell of the sheep and removed the half set within a egg gamete, placed the full set in the now empty gamete, then placed the egg back into a female sheep, the egg with a full set of chromosomes begins dividing exponentially and as a result the sheep gives birth to a clone. Much of this process is done in invitrofertilization for the purpose of surrogate moms and females with poor fertility. the only difference is that in invitrofertilization they take the dna from both parents instead of just one. so using this blueprint they could theoretically bring back any animal so long as they have its dna. In fact there has been legitamate discussions about rather or not to attempt to clone a willy mammoth and also a dodo bird. (all restrictions on cloning and attemptive cloning are from an ethical standpoint) I guess he said it was sci-fi because we don't currently have a source for intact dino dna, but still how can he be so sure that we never will?

fun fact: velociraptors or "swift thieves(after translation)" were actually only about .5m tall (1.6ft), the dinosaurs depicted across the movies were modeled after Utharaptors (translates Utah's Predator) which stood over 2m(~7ft) tall and were 7m(23ft) long. The size of the famed "raptor claw" was about 24cm(9.4in). Of course as the name sugests Velociraptors and Utharaptors are closely related and share a close common ancestor. Oh and if you've heard of megaraptors the fact is that they were real but were actually a relative of the Tyrannosaurus or "tyrant lizard"

To my understanding, fossil fuel comes from the carboniforous period; the "Age of the Plants". Because there was little to no herbivory on the plants in that time, plant life expanded and covered up almost all the land. These "trees" grew so large and the population was so big that most of the CO2 was converted to O2, which is also the reason why dragonflies were able to grow the size of seagulls. But the CO2 levels dropped so low that the "greenhouse" effect of this molecule was not enough to hold the temperature of Earth. The planet cooled down and a lot of the plants died. Swamps were created and the fallen over trees were submerged and then buried by sediment. In time the pressure on these "carcasses" created the fuel we use today.

If there is one chance to visit the past, I would want to see this period. Ferns were as big as trees and insects the size of pets is as alien as any other habitable planet we might discover.

Even though Mr. Horner seems like a fine dude, I'm still disappointed that they decided not to depict (at least some) dinosaurs with feathers. 

When it comes to spreading ideas into the minds of the general public, Hollywood has the best position to do so. And boy they can sometimes do a heck of a job (Cameron on the enviroment with Avatar, Nolan on our position in space and time with Interstellar).

So, by not depicting dinosaurs as they probably were, probably simply because velociraptors with feathers look less cool for the average viewer, I believe the creators of the Jurassic World are being socially irresponsible. 

Extraordinary film makers are those, who make their decisions primarily by something else than profit.

Dinosaur facts:
    T. Rex lived closer in time to us than it did stegosaurus.
    Dilophosaurus had neither venom nor umbrella necks. (At least, we have no reason to believe they did.)
    Pterodactyl and Liopleurodon were not dinosaurs.
    Dinosaurs are not lizards, despite the word meaning "Terrible Lizard".
    They did not have overlapping scales.
    Dinosaurs were neither cold nor warm-blooded, but a different system similar to warmblooded. (I'm not 100% sure about that fact though.)
     Oviraptor means "egg taker" and was named such, because it was thought to steel eggs, because the first specimen discovered was found atop what were thought to be Protoceratops eggs. Later discoveries indicate that it was actually brooding its own eggs.

I'm no paleontologist, so tell me if you see an error I've made. And please, add more fun facts.
